data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various tailed primates of the suborder Anthropoidea, including the macaques, baboons, capuchins, and marmosets, and excluding the apes.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A nonhuman ape. Not in scientific use.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: One who behaves in a way suggestive of a monkey, as a mischievous child or a mimic.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The iron block of a pile driver.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A person who is mocked, duped, or made to appear a fool.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: They made a monkey out of him.

data.text: Used as a disparaging term for a person with dark skin.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To play, fiddle, trifle, or tamper with something.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: Who was monkeying with my cell phone?

data.text: To behave in a mischievous or apish manner.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
